questions.text: Which of the following non-hormonal drugs can be used as a first-line agent to reduce bleeding in AUB?

A 48-year-old multiparous woman with a complete family came to the OPD with complaints of painful menstruation and lower pelvic pain for the past 6 months. Investigations led to a diagnosis of adenomyosis. What is the most appropriate definitive treatment for her condition?
questions.explanation:
Medical Methods

Surgical Methods
  • Combined OCPs and progestin-only regimens: Improves dysmenorrhea and menorrhagia (Option A)
  • NSAIDs: For pain and menorrhagia.
  • LNG-IUS: Reduce Menorrhagia
  • GnRH agonists: For adenomyosis-related sub-fertility or as pre-surgical relief.
  • Danazol: For menorrhagia and pain.
  • Conservative surgery: Preserves fertility for women desiring children. It includes:
    • Adenomyomectomy: Difficulty in completely removing adenomyoma ➜ Risk of recurrence. (Option C)
    • Uterine mass reduction (laparotomy or laparoscopy)
    • Uterine artery embolisation (UAE): To relieve symptoms) (Option D)
  • Definitive surgery: Total Hysterectomy (Option B)

questions.text: A 40 year old female presents with AUB associated with chronic pelvic pain for the past two years. TVS shows anteroposterior asymmetry of the uterus and heterogeneous myometrial texture. What will you most likely see on HPE if this patient is diagnosed with adenomyosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Glandular endometrial tissue surrounded by stromal cells in myometrium

options.label: B
options.text: Hyperplastic endometrial glands with mitotic bodies

options.label: C
options.text: Whorled pattern of well-differentiated smooth muscle fibres

options.label: D
options.text: Necrotic endometrial tissue with chronic inflammation and lymphocytic infiltrate

questions.correct_answer: A. Glandular endometrial tissue surrounded by stromal cells in myometrium
questions.explanation:
Disease

Histopathological findings

Adenomyosis

Glandular endometrial tissue surrounded by stromal cells in myometrium.

Endometrial hyperplasia

Hyperplastic endometrial glands with mitotic bodies.

Leiomyoma

Whorled pattern of well-differentiated smooth muscle fibres.

Endometritis

Necrotic endometrial tissue with lymphocytic infiltrate.

questions.text: A 34 year old female presents with chronic, progressive pelvic pain for the past three years and a history of heavy menstrual bleeding. Clinical examination reveals an enlarged uterus corresponding to a size of 10 weeks. An MRI was performed after an inconclusive transvaginal ultrasound (TVS). Which of the following is NOT a typical feature of MRI for adenomyosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Contrast enhancement does not assist in the diagnosis of adenomyosis.

options.label: B
options.text: Presence of myometrial cysts is a characteristic feature.

options.label: C
options.text: Myometrial foci appear to have high intensity on the T2 weighted scale.

options.label: D
options.text: Junctional zone measures less than 12 mm.

questions.correct_answer: D. Junctional zone measures less than 12 mm.

questions.text: During an outpatient visit, a 31 year old woman presents with complaints of dysmenorrhea and postmenopausal spotting. Upon assessment, she is categorised under ASRM Stage 1 for her endometriosis. Which structure is not evaluated for scoring in the ASRM endometriosis staging system?
questions.explanation:
Stage / Classification

Score

Minimal

1-5

Mild

6 - 15

Moderate

16 - 40

Severe

> 40

questions.text: A 35 year old woman undergoes laparoscopy for chronic pelvic pain and infertility. The surgeon observes multiple dark brown lesions on the ovaries and pelvic peritoneum. A biopsy is taken and sent for histopathological examination. Which of the following histopathological findings is most consistent with the diagnosis of endometriosis in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Presence of endometrial glands and stroma without hemosiderin-laden macrophages

options.label: B
options.text: Presence of endometrial glands and stroma with hemosiderin-laden macrophages

options.label: C
options.text: Presence of only endometrial glands without stroma

options.label: D
options.text: Presence of only hemosiderin-laden macrophages without glands or stroma

questions.correct_answer: B. Presence of endometrial glands and stroma with hemosiderin-laden macrophages

questions.text: A 32 year old woman presents with chronic pelvic pain, dysmenorrhea, and dyspareunia. During laparoscopy, the gynaecologist observes endometriotic lesions in multiple locations. Which of the following sites is least likely to be affected by endometriosis in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Pelvic sites (Most common)
  • Ovaries (Commonest)
  • Fallopian tubes
  • Uterosacral ligaments
  • Pouch of Douglas (rectouterine pouch)
  • Pelvic peritoneum

Other pelvic organs
  • Bladder and Ureters
  • Rectum and sigmoid colon

Abdominal sites
  • Appendix
  • Intestine
  • Umbilicus

Surgical scars
  • Cesarean section scars
  • Episiotomy scars

Thoracic sites (rare)

  • Lungs
  • Diaphragm

Extrapelvic sites (very rare)
  • Spine
  • Eyes

questions.text: A 28 year old woman presents with endometriosis lesions on her abdominal surgical scars following a cesarean section. Which theory of endometriosis development best explains this presentation?
questions.explanation:
Theory

Site

Sampson’s Theory of Implantation/ Theory of Retrograde menstruation
  • Ovary
  • Pouch of Douglas
  • Uterosacral ligament

Halban's theory of lymphatic spread

Umbilicus

Ivanoff's theory of coelomic metaplasia

Lungs

Direct implantation

Scar endometriosis

questions.text: A 40 year old woman with three children who has been using OCPs for 5 years is a current smoker, has a BMI of 27, menarche at 13, and has a family history of endometriosis, is concerned about her risk of developing the condition. Which best describes her endometriosis risk profile?

options.label: A
options.text: High risk due to family history

options.label: B
options.text: High risk due to increased age

options.label: C
options.text: Low risk due to multiple protective factors

questions.correct_answer: C. Low risk due to multiple protective factors
questions.explanation:
Risk Factors

Protective Factors
  • Nulliparous (Increased estrogen)
  • Early Menarche
  • Late Menopause
  • Low BMI
  • Multiparity
  • OCP Use
  • Smoking

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of secondary amenorrhea and pelvic pain. She reports intermittent fever and significant weight loss over the past few months. On physical examination, there is tenderness in the lower abdomen, and an adnexal mass is palpated. Given these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?

A 29-year-old woman presents with complaints of infertility and chronic lower abdominal pain for the past year. She mentions recent unintentional weight loss and occasional night sweats. Her menstrual cycles have been regular, but she has experienced heavier-than-usual periods over the past six months. Considering her symptoms and clinical history, the clinician suspects endometrial tuberculosis and decides to perform an endometrial biopsy for diagnosis. Which is the best time to perform an endometrial biopsy to diagnose endometrial tuberculosis?

options.label: D
options.text: Any time during the menstrual cycle

questions.correct_answer: C. During the late premenstrual phase

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with a complaint of post-coital bleeding for the past few months. She reports no other gynecological symptoms, and her last Pap smear was normal. On pelvic examination, a small fleshy, red mass protruding from the cervical os is seen. What is the most likely cause of her post-coital bleeding?
questions.explanation:
Cause

Description

Cervical Polyps

Benign growths on the cervix that can bleed, especially when irritated.

Cervical Ectropion (Cervical Erosion)

Exposed glandular cells on the outer surface of the cervix are prone to bleeding after intercourse.

Cervical Dysplasia

Abnormal changes in cervical cells that may cause bleeding during or after sex.

Sexually Transmitted Infections (STIs)

Infections like chlamydia, gonorrhoea, or HPV can cause cervicitis and bleeding after intercourse.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman with one child presents with menorrhagia for the past 5 months and a long-standing large, intramural uterine fibroid. She wants to preserve her fertility. After failed medical interventions to control the abnormal uterine bleeding, which surgical intervention is appropriate for this patient?
questions.explanation:
• Uterine fibroid
  • History of previous surgery
  • Young woman desirous of pregnancy
  • Adenomyosis can cause dysmenorrhoea
  • Genital infections
  • Uterine cancer

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with infertility. Laboratory tests reveal low levels of luteinising hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH). Which of the following is the most likely cause of his infertility?
questions.explanation:
1. Pre-testicular (central): endocrine disorders (low LH and FSH)
  • Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism/ Kallman syndrome
  • Endocrine: Hyperprolactinemia (Option C), obesity, thyroid disorder
  • Drugs: Antihypertensives, Antipsychotics

2. Testicular (peripheral): Intrinsic disorders (High FSH and LH)
  • Genetic disorders:
    • Klinefelter syndrome (Most common) (Option B)
    • Immotile cilia (Kartagener) syndrome
  • Varicocele: Most common reversible cause (Option A)
  • Undescended testes
  • Testicular torsion
  • Mumps orchitis
  • Heat exposure: Miners
  • Toxins: smoking, radiation, drug abuse
  • Oligoasthenoteratozoospermia

3. Post-testicular: (Normal LH and FSH)
  • Congenital: Absent vas deferens (cystic fibrosis), Young’s syndrome
  • Obstruction: Epididymal and Ejaculatory duct obstruction (Option D)
  • Acquired: Genital TB, gonorrhoea
  • Surgical: herniorrhaphy, vasectomy, bladder neck surgery
  • Other: Retrograde ejaculation, hypospadias

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to the OPD with complaints of irregular and painful menstruation for the past 5 months. Her urine pregnancy test is negative, and other blood reports are within normal limits. Considering her age and presentation, which of the following investigations should be considered as the next step for diagnosing the cause of AUB?

A 38-year-old obese woman presents with heavy and prolonged vaginal bleeding for the past six months, lasting more than 10 days. Which of the following could NOT be a possible cause of bleeding according to the PALM-COEIN classification?

The male partner should be treated along with the female partner in which of the following conditions? i) Candidiasis ii) Bacterial vaginosis iii) Trichomoniasis iv) Gonorrhoea v) Chlamydia vi) Chancroid
questions.explanation:
Condition

Male Partner Treatment

Candidiasis
  • Male partners need not be treated except when symptomatic.
  • Use nystatin ointment locally for a few days after each instance of coitus.
  • Condom use is preferred during treatment.

Trichomoniasis
  • Follow the same treatment as the female partner:
    • Metronidazole 500 mg BD for 1 week, or a single 2 g dose.
    • Tinidazole 2 g single dose is also effective.
  • Use a condom during coitus until the female partner is cured.

Gonorrhoea
  • Cover gonorrhea, syphilis, and chlamydia.
  • Ceftriaxone 250 mg IM + Azithromycin 1 g PO once, or Doxycycline 100 mg PO BID for 7 days.
  • Use a condom until both partners are disease-free.

Chlamydia
  • It should be treated with the same regimen as the female partner to reduce resistance or recurrence.
  • Azithromycin 1 g once, or Doxycycline 100 mg BID for 7 days.
  • Abstain from sex until both partners are treated and asymptomatic.

Chancroid
  • Ceftriaxone 250 mg IM single dose, Azithromycin 1 g PO single dose, or Erythromycin 500 mg PO every 8 hours for 7 days.
  • Longer treatment for HIV-positive patients.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with an intense burning sensation and thick vaginal discharge. She reports no foul odour with erythema on pelvic examination. A wet mount preparation is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Causative organism
  • Candida albicans (Dimorphic fungi)
    • Blastospores: Transmission and colonisation
    • Mycelia: Tissue invasion & adherence

Symptoms
  • Pruritus, burning, and splash dysuria
  • Erythema and oedema on pelvic examination

Diagnosis
  • Curdy white discharge resembles cottage cheese
  • Vaginal wall plaque: petechiae when removed
  • Microscopy on KOH preparation: budding yeast and pseudohyphae (image).
  • Culture: Bismuth Glycine Glucose Yeast agar (BiGGYagar) or Nickerson agar (selective for candidiasis).

Types
  1. Uncomplicated candidiasis:
    1. In immunocompetant women
    2. Good prognosis
    3. Causative organism: C. albicans
  2. Complicated candidiasis:
    1. In immunocompromised women: DM, TB, pregnancy and chemotherapy patients
    2. Recurrent and difficult-to-treat.
    3. Causative organism: Non albican species like C. tropicalis, glabrata

questions.text: A 27-year-old female presents with a yellow vaginal discharge and itching. A pelvic examination revealed an erythematous cervix. A wet mount preparation is shown below. Which of the following statements is not true about this patient's condition?

options.label: A
options.text: It is the most common cause of non-viral sexually transmitted diseases worldwide.

options.label: B
options.text: The preferred treatment is a single dose of metronidazole.

options.label: C
options.text: Repeat NAAT testing after 3 days is required to confirm eradication of the infection.

options.label: D
options.text: Sexual partners should be treated simultaneously to prevent reinfection.

questions.correct_answer: C. Repeat NAAT testing after 3 days is required to confirm eradication of the infection.
questions.explanation:
Causative organism
  • Trichomonas vaginalis (anaerobic flagellate protozoan).

Clinical findings
  • Severe irritation and pruritus.
  • Foul, thin, greenish-yellow, frothy discharge.
  • Dysuria, dyspareunia, vulvar pruritus, and lower abdominal pain.

Diagnosis
  • Vaginal pH >4.5
  • Microscopy: motile trichomonads.
  • Colpitis macularis (strawberry vagina): subepithelial haemorrhage on cervix/vagina.
  • Lab-based NAATs for trichomonal DNA: (Option C)
    • Repeat test if suspect persisted infection/ re-infection.
    • Not distinguishing live from dead (adequately treated) trichomonas; hence, repeat testing delayed for 3 weeks.

Risk factor
  • Increase incidence with age.

Treatment
  • DOC: Metronidazole 500 mg (400 mg) BD for 7 days or 2 g orally once (Option B).
  • If allergy: desensitisation.
  • Treat sex partners (Option D).
  • Abstain sex and condom use.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female presents with severe lower abdominal pain, fever, and purulent vaginal discharge. She has bilateral adnexal and cervical motion tenderness on examination. Investigations show elevated WBC, positive swabs for N. gonorrhoeae and C. trachomatis, and bilateral tubo-ovarian abscesses on ultrasound. She is admitted to the ward. What is the most appropriate inpatient treatment for severe PID?

options.label: A
options.text: Oral Doxycycline 100 mg BD and Metronidazole 500 mg BD

options.label: B
options.text: I.M Ceftriaxone 250 mg OD and oral Azithromycin 1 g OD

options.label: C
options.text: I.V Cefoxitin 2 g every 6 hours and Doxycycline 100 mg BD

options.label: D
options.text: Oral Levofloxacin 500 mg OD and Metronidazole 500 mg BD

questions.correct_answer: C. I.V Cefoxitin 2 g every 6 hours and Doxycycline 100 mg BD
questions.explanation:
In-patient antibiotic therapy

Parenteral regimen A

Cefoxitin 2 g IV every 6 hours for 7 days + Doxycycline 100 mg PO BD for 14 days

Parenteral regimen B

Clindamycin 900 mg IV every 8 hours + Gentamicin 2 mg/kg IV (loading dose), followed by 1.5 mg/kg IV (maintenance dose) every 8 hours

• Aztreonam (2 g IV slowly) is similar to aminoglycoside and can be used. It has no renal toxicity, but is more expensive.

Alternative parenteral regimen

Ampicillin-sulbactam 3 g IV every 6 hours 3-5 days + Doxycycline 100 mg orally BID for 14 days

questions.text: A 24-year-old sexually active woman presents to the clinic with lower abdominal pain, fever, and unusual vaginal discharge. She is diagnosed with pelvic inflammatory disease. What is the most appropriate initial treatment regimen for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Azithromycin 1 g PO OD + Metronidazole 500 mg PO BD X 14 days

options.label: B
options.text: Cefixime 400 mg PO single dose + Doxycycline 100 mg PO BD X 14 days + Metronidazole 500 mg PO BD X 14 days

options.label: C
options.text: Levofloxacin 500 mg PO OD X 14 days, and Metronidazole 500 mg PO BD X 14 days

options.label: D
options.text: Amoxicillin-clavulanate 875 mg/125 mg PO BD X 14 days, and Doxycycline 100 mg PO BD X 14 days

questions.correct_answer: B. Cefixime 400 mg PO single dose + Doxycycline 100 mg PO BD X 14 days + Metronidazole 500 mg PO BD X 14 days
questions.explanation:
Out-patient antibiotic therapy

Ceftriaxone 250 mg IM single dose or

Cefoxitin, 2g IM single dose and probenecid, 1 g PO single dose or

Injection Cefotaxime IV

Add Doxycycline 100 mg PO, BD for 14 days with or without Metronidazole 500 mg PO BD for 14 days

Option A
  • Azithromycin is effective against Chlamydia trachomatis.
  • Azithromycin does not cover other pathogens, such as Neisseria gonorrhoeae and anaerobes.
  • Metronidazole targets anaerobic organisms, but this combination lacks coverage for Neisseria gonorrhoeae, making it suboptimal.

Option C
  • Levofloxacin is effective against organisms causing PID, such as Neisseria gonorrhoeae and anaerobes.
  • However, it is generally reserved as an alternative therapy when other first-line antibiotics cannot be used.
  • While Levofloxacin could be used as a first-line therapy, it is not recommended due to antibiotic resistance as it is used as a second line treatment for tuberculosis

Option D
  • Amoxicillin-clavulanate is broad-spectrum and effective against many bacterial infections.
    • It does not adequately cover Neisseria gonorrhoeae.
  • Doxycycline covers Chlamydia trachomatis but not the polymicrobial nature of PID.
  • Therefore, this combination is suboptimal for treating PID according to current guidelines.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common organism associated with pelvic inflammatory disease?
questions.explanation:
Acute

Chronic
  • Neisseria gonorrhoeae
  • Chlamydia trachomatis
  • E.coli
  • Mycoplasma genitalium
  • Anaerobes: Including Bacteroides species (Mixed infections)
  • Gardnerella vaginalis
  • Trichomonas vaginalis
  • Streptococci: Including Group B Streptococcus
  • Mycobacterium tuberculosis
  • Actinomyces israelii

questions.text: All of the following are indications for intrauterine insemination except:
questions.explanation:
Indications for IUI

C/I (Prior correctional treatment required)
  • Cervical factors infertility: Anti-sperm antibodies in cervical mucous (Option A).
  • Mild-moderate male factors: Anejaculation, anorgasmia, retrograde ejaculation (Option B).
  • Unexplained infertility (Option C).
  • Uterine factors: Fibroids, endometrial polyp, intrauterine adhesions.
  • Tubal factors: Occlusion.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presents to the clinic for evaluation of her fertility status. She has been trying to conceive for over a year without success. Which of the following is the single best test for assessing her ovarian reserve?
questions.explanation:
Test Name

Description

Key Points

Anti-Müllerian Hormone (AMH)

A hormone produced by ovarian antral follicles.
  • Blood test reflecting the remaining quantity of eggs.
  • Not affected by the menstrual cycle.
  • The single best test for assessing her ovarian reserve

Antral Follicle Count (AFC)

Ultrasound count of the small follicles (antral follicles) within the ovaries.
  • Direct visual assessment.
  • Can vary with the cycle.
  • Baseline assessment and monitoring.

Follicle-Stimulating Hormone (FSH)

Measures the level of FSH, which stimulates the growth of ovarian follicles.
  • Blood test done on day 3 of the menstrual cycle.
  • Initial screening of ovarian function.

Estradiol (E2)

Measures the level of estradiol, an estrogen produced by growing follicles.
  • Blood test done on day 3 of the menstrual cycle.
  • High levels can mask high FSH levels, so they are used in conjunction with FSH.

Inhibin B

Measures the level of inhibin B, which reflects the number of antral follicles.
  • Blood test on day 5 of the menstrual cycle.

Clomiphene Citrate Challenge Test (CCCT)

Measures FSH and estradiol before and after taking clomiphene citrate.
  • Two blood tests: day 3 and day 10.
  • Higher FSH levels on day 10 indicate lower reserve.
  • Used for detailed functional assessment.

questions.text: Match the following semen analysis terms with their correct definitions: 1. Aspermia a. Reduced sperm motility 2. Azoospermia b. Complete absence of semen 3. Asthenozoospermia c. Absence of sperm in the semen 4. Necrozoospermia d. High percentage of dead sperm in the semen
questions.explanation:
Condition

Definition

Aspermia

Complete absence of semen

Azoospermia

Absence of sperm in the semen

Asthenozoospermia

Reduced sperm motility

Necrozoospermia

Higher percentage of dead/ non-viable sperm in the semen

Hypospermia

Low semen volume (<1.4 ml)

Oligospermia

Sperm count <16 million per ml

Severe oligospermia

Sperm count <5 million per ml

Polyzoospermia

Sperm count >350 million per ml

Teratozoospermia

>70% sperms with abnormal morphology
